94.heading: Riffian People.
94.title: "The Desert Panther"
94.author: by Pierre La Rue ; Ken Batefield, pencils
notes: Begins: "A great riff tribe dwelt somewhere out in the sandy wastes of North Africa, lived under the leadership of the mysterious Desert Panther. Little was know of this strange figure, except that he raided only the evil slave caravans, turned his captives over to the authorities. But now, in the streets of El Kofabah, Captain Terry Thunder and several officials are watching."

100.heading: Rifkin, Adam.
100.title: Shmobots
100.author: written by Adam Rifkin ; art by Les Toil ; cover art by Brian Clarke ; lettered by Johnny Lowe.
notes: Summary (from SkyRiver): When the government starts a project to create a race of worker robots, a low bidder contract produces an army of lazy, stupid robots instead. Dubbed shmobots, this new slacker subculture is determined to stay out of society, even when a shmobot serial killer is on the loose.

113.heading: Riflemen.
113.title: "The Return of Morgan the Raider" 10 p. in Top Secrets, no. 9
113.author: [No author]
notes: Begins: "Few fighters of the American Civil War were more daring than the Confederate general John H. Morgan, whose mounted riflemen, a division of 2500 men, were the first to be termed 'rough riders.' Yet Morgan, by that very daring was captured by the Union forces at the time he was most needed. How he escaped and returned to his command was the 'top secret' of its time."

120.heading: Rifles.
120.title: "La Caravane Perdue"
120.author: texte d'Albert Bonneau
120.appears_in: 16 p. in French-Bill, Cavalier du Far-West, no. 1 (4e trimestre 1953).
notes: Summary: Guillaume Francoeur, nicknamed "Bill," and his family of French origin are part of a wagon train heading west under the command of Wagon Boss Drackton. their guide, Nelanton, comes back after a day's absence to report that Comanches are blocking their way. Bill is excited that he'll finally see Indians. Bill sneaks out, overhears the Indians' plan, and gives a warning in time for the settlers to drive off an attack. They give him the nickname "French-Bill" for that. The Indians come back, and Bill distinguishes himself by killing some with his Uncle Joe's rifle. Nelanton is gone for a long time again, and so Joe and Bill ride out to find him. The Indians have Nelanton tied to a pole, but the sentry is sleeping so Joe and Bill effect a rescue. The next episode will be called "Sur la piste des buffalos."

notes: Begins: "To be a Texas Ranger, all a young Texan needed was a good horse, a sixgun, and a rifle, and the ability to use them expertly. Doug Dobler was youthfully sure he was practically in when he started for Austin, but Ranger-hating Doc Vesey got in his way!"

138.heading: Rifles.
138.title: "Thrillkill"
138.author: story, Jim Stenstrum ; art, Neal Adams
notes: "Joe Bobby Lang was young. Shy. Unable to communicate. And it seemed no one wanted to bother with a lonely, disturbed youngster. But Bobby found a sure-fire attention grabber. He went out on a roof. Pulled out his rifle. And started pumping bullets into a rush hour crowd!"
